variant.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a Microwave Landing System (MLS) compared with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)?

options.text: It is insensitive to geographical site and can be installed at sites where it is not possible to use an ILS
There is no restriction on the number of ground installations that can be operated because there is an unlimited number of frequency channels available
The installation does not require to have a separate method (marker beacons or DME) to determine range
It does not require a separate azimuth (localiser) and elevation (azimuth) transmitter

variant.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a Microwave Landing System (MLS) compared with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)?

options.text: It is insensitive to geographical site and can be installed at sites where it is not possible to use an ILS
It does not require a separate azimuth -localiser- and elevation -azimuth- transmitter
There is no restriction on the number of ground installations that can be operated because there is an unlimited number of frequency channels available
The installation does not require to have a separate method -marker beacons or DME- to determine range

variant.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of a Microwave Landing System (MLS) compared with an Instrument Landing System (ILS)?

options.text: It is insensitive to geographical site and can be installed at sites where it is not possible to use an ILS.
The installation does not require to have a separate method (marker beacons or DME) to determine range.
It does not require a separate azimuth (localiser) and elevation (azimuth) transmitter.
There is no restriction on the number of ground installations that can be operated because there is an unlimited number of frequency channels available.

variant.question: A multimode receiver which can receive ILS, MLS and GBAS inputs is fitted to an aircraft.The advantage of this type of receiver is that it...

options.text: reduces training requirements.
allows an approach to be flown using inputs from all three systems.
is more accurate.
automatically identifies and connects to nearby radio aids.

variant.question: Would an MLS facility be useless if the DME is unserviceable?

options.text: No, it can be used for straight in approaches like ILS but without distance information.
Yes, because both facilities are frequency paired.
No, it can still be used for MLS approaches but without distance indications in the cockpit.
Yes, an MLS facility uses an integrated DME system and if the DME fails, the MLS also fails.

variant.question: A DME-P is added to Microwave Landing System (MLS) to...

options.text: Obtain three dimensional positions.
Support the time referenced scanning beam.
Assure a constant angular velocity of the azimuth and elevation sweep.
Allow straight in approaches.

variant.question: Which of the following could give sufficient guidance to the pilot when flying a curved MLS approach?

options.text: Flight director bars
Radio magnetic indicator
Omnibearing indicator
Course deviation indicator

variant.question: Which of the following systems provides distance information?

options.text: DME
ADF
VDF
VOR

variant.question: A pilot activates the approach (APP) mode of his autopilot while he is still high above the glide slope. What can be a possible result?

options.text: The aircraft can capture a false glide path.
The aircraft can initiate a premature descent and fly into terrain.
The aircraft speed can decrease below the appropriate approach speed.
The aircraft altitude can increase.
